name: AIDS Action Europe
goal:
“ AIDS: because the global fight against HIV and AIDS is what unites our members
Action: because we want to move beyond networking and towards concrete actions
Europe: because we need to collaborate on a shared agenda in Europe”
Peter van Rooijen’s spoke these words when representing AIDS Action Europe’s (AAE) interim Steering Committee at the
Open Forum on AIDS Action in Europe in March 2004.13 years later, his words have lost neither their power nor relevance.
HIV continues to be a major European public health concern, with primary issues revolving around:
→ The fact that HIV is still concentrated in key populations (men who have sex with men (MSM), people who use injection drugs (PWID), sex workers and people coming from high endemic countries).
→ The need for maintained and expanded harm reduction programmes across the region.
→ The need to promote voluntary counselling and testing (VCT) particularly within key populations, in order to ensure
diagnosis and initiation of treatment and care.
→ The need for equitable access to treatment and care across Europe, with particular attention paid to Eastern Europe
and Central Asia.
→ The need for improved access to prevention, treatment and care for migrant populations.
The AAE Steering Committee has defined an overall strategy and clear agenda spanning 2015–2017 that align AAE’s workwith these growing concerns. Through this, we will strengthen our response to the epidemic, maintain our commitments and provide a framework in which we can prioritise our actions. It is AAE’s duty to keep HIV/AIDS and co-infections as priorities on EU, national and regional health agendas. AAE will build the advocacy capacity of civil society organisations, in order to mitigate the obstacles that limit universal access to prevention, treatment, care and affordable of medicines.
Who we are
Founded in 2004, AAE is an international network comprised of 440 NGOs, networks, AIDS service organisations, activist- and community-based groups of people living with HIV (PLWH) and other key populations. Members span the EU/EEA, Central Asia, the Caucasus region and Israel.
Our Vision:
AAE’s vision is that people living with, affected by and vulnerable to HIV/AIDS enjoy a life free from stigma, discrimination and persecution, and that they have equal access to prevention, treatment, care and support across Europe and Central Asia.
Our Mission:
AAE’s mission is to connect civil society in order to work towards a more effective response to the HIV epidemic in Europe and Central Asia. We strive for the best standards of human rights protection and universal access to prevention, treatment, care and support. We aim to reduce health inequalities, paying particular attention to key populations.
Our Strategic Objectives: what we aim for:
AAE strengthens the effectiveness of civil society’s response to the HIV epidemic in the region through three strategic
objectives.
→ We serve as a gateway to members, driving forward advocacy for HIV policy change.
→ We provide a platform for regular knowledge exchange and networking.
→ We develop a stronger and more effective organisation and network.
interests: Budget, Communication, Education and training, Employment and Social Affairs, Humanitarian aid and civil protection, International co-operation and development, Public Health, Trans-European Networks
euInitiatives:
Since the start of the EU HIV/AIDS Civil Society Forum in 2005, AAE has co-chaired the forum together with the European AIDS Treatment Group. AAE initiates and supports advocacy efforts both at international and national level in close collaboration with other stakeholders and organisations as for instance:
o In February the CSF Coordination Team met with the new head of the unit Crisis Management and Preparedness in Health in the Commission, Michael Huebel and Wolfgang Philipp. A new policy framework was on the agenda as much as the role of civil society in the future. Both parties claimed it to be a fruitful and helpful meeting. After the meeting the CSF Coordination Team sent action points to the Commission based on the discussion.
o In March 2016 the two CSF co-Chairs participated in the ECDC HIV Network and ECDC-WHO HIV Surveillance Meetings in Bratislava
o In April the joint application of AAE and EATG as CSF to the Conference Coordinating Committee (CCC) for Amsterdam 2018 was approved.
o The High Level Meeting on Ending AIDS in New York in June gave the opportunity to meet with national governments representatives, including Charmaine Gauci, the representative from Malta, who is going to hold the EU-Presidency in the first half of 2017 to discuss the presidency agenda on HIV, TB and hepatitis in order to highlight civil society perspectives in the response to HIV, TB and viral Hepatitis
o World AIDS Conference Amsterdam 2018: The EU HIV Civil Society Forum was appointed to the Conference Coordinating Committee of the World AIDS Conference in Amsterdam in July 2016. The co-chairs of the EU HIV CSF took part in the first meeting of the Committee in Durban.
o The CSF co-chairs took part in the ECDC’s STI and HIV Coordination Committee Meeting in September 2016.
o The transition from international to domestic funding leads to significant problems in countries where the GFATM is withdrawing. In particular prevention and harm reduction services run by NGOs can often not be maintained, as for instance Montenegro’s recent example of concentrated epidemic following the retreat of the GFATM. The CSF contributed to a joint letter to the Estonian EU-Presidency in September 2016, which will host the EU Presidency in the 2nd half (July-December) of 2017, to address this issue.
o In October 2016 the EU HIV/AIDS CSF coordinated a letter from civil society and professional associations in the field of TB, HIV and viral Hepatitis to European Commission Vice President Timmermans requesting Commission engagement in updating the EU policy framework and to integrate some of the work. The chairs also encouraged CSF members to engage with their respective MoH prior to the Meeting of Ministers in Bratislava on 2-3October 2016 where the topic was to be discussed in the context of EU action with respect to MDR-TB.
o In October 2016 CSF Members were addressed to engage with their respective European Parliament Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) representatives regarding the discussion in the European Parliament on October 12 on Health.
o Sini Pasanen, CSF Co-Chair, was invited in October 2016 to give an opening speech at the forthcoming EU Presidency Conference ‘Fast-tracking the end of AIDS in Europe - practical evidence-based interventions’ that will be hosted by the government of Malta, in collaboration with ECDC, at the end of January 2017.
o In October 2016 Luís Mendão participated as CSF co-chair in the WHO European Region conference in Minsk, Belarus.
o The CSF Coordination Team was invited to meet Commissioner Andriukaitis in November 2016. The CSF representatives were accompanied by representatives of ELPA and TB Europe Coalition.
